name: Diwali
description: The festival of lights, celebrated by Hindus, Jains, Sikhs, and some Buddhists. It symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.

name: Holi
description: The festival of colors, primarily celebrated by Hindus. It signifies the triumph of good over evil, the arrival of spring, and a day to play, laugh, forget and forgive, and repair broken relationships.

name: Navratri
regions: All over India, especially Gujarat, West Bengal, and Northern India
description: A nine-night Hindu festival celebrated in many parts of India. It literally means 'nine nights' and is dedicated to the worship of the Hindu deity Durga.

name: Eid al-Fitr
description: Celebrated by Muslims worldwide, marking the end of the month-long dawn-to-sunset fasting of Ramadan. It is a day of joy, gratitude, and charity.

name: Pongal
description: A harvest festival celebrated by Tamils. It is dedicated to the Sun God (Surya) and marks the beginning of the Tamil month Thai.

name: Durga Puja
description: An annual Hindu festival in the Indian subcontinent that reveres the goddess Durga. It is particularly popular in West Bengal.

name: Onam
description: An annual harvest festival celebrated by people of Kerala, India. It commemorates King Mahabali's annual visit and is a ten-day festival.

name: Janmashtami
regions: All over India, especially Mathura and Vrindavan
description: The annual Hindu festival that celebrates the birth of Krishna, the eighth avatar of Vishnu.

name: Ganesh Chaturthi
description: A Hindu festival celebrating the birth of Ganesha, the elephant-headed god. It typically lasts for 10 days.

name: Baisakhi
description: A historic and religious festival in Sikhism and Hinduism. It is the spring harvest festival for Sikhs and Hindus.
